moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4: This move attempts to exploit the vulnerability at f7.
moves.3... Bc5 4. O-O Nf6 5. d3 d6 6. Bg5: Probably too easily dealt with, but if not dealt with well, white will end up with a strong position.
moves.8... Be6 9. Nd5 Bxd5 10. exd5 Nd4 11. Nx: ? Sinply loses the pawn as 14...exf4 15.Rxf4 g5 loses a bishop, and it may take black a few moves, but once the counter-attack gets rolling, it will provide black compesation for the exposed King.
moves.14... c6: ??  White gets to sidestep the blunder.
moves.16... bxc6 17. Qd2: !  Moves like these are difficult to react to in quick time when the player misses the idea behind it.
moves.18. Rxf6: Black saw no need to sidestep the pin by playing Qd6, but now he has to surrender the queen.
moves.18... gxf6 19. Qxh6: And the point is delivered home.
moves.19... Bd8: Good, but insufficient.  Too little, and too late.
moves.20. Rf1 Qd6 21. Rxf6: Black now must surrender the queen or face mate.  After 21.Bxf6 Bxf6 22.Qxf6 Qxf6, white is sitting pretty with a plus 6 material advantage using the common scoring system.
moves.21... Qc5 22. Qg5+: And I missed an even prettier mate: 22.Rg6# which makes the formerly appealing mate with the Queen in hazard look ugly.
